posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: Is there any way to send UDP data to the DS ? I speculate that the controller rumble sends a message from the robot to ds using UDP, is there a way i can simulate that to make a UDP receiver which acts like a fake controller, that can receive multiple inputs?

Can you clarify what you are trying to do? Are you trying to send data to the FRC Driver Station, or trying to send data to the laptop (in that case Network Tables would be better)? This seems like an xy problem .

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
The protocol has been reverse engineered. The short answer is it’s multiple streams of data, formatted in a specific way that the driver station expects.

The “thing at the other end” will have to act like a whole roboRIO, not just one joystick.

I have spent some time recently trying to make a box that, to the DS , appeared like a regular roboRIO. I was only partially successful: the DS could connect to it and enable/disable it, but things like sending all the detailed joystick data proved harder than I had time for. The big issue was the DS (reasonably) doesn’t provide feedback if you get packet sequencing and info wrong, so it was super hard to debug.

Yes - probably an X/Y problem - can you describe at a higher level what you’re trying to do?

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: send data to the laptop, but with UDP instead of TCP so that it transfers way faster.

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: I want software that can create a fake controller that will be detected by the DS , and that software lets you send inputs to the rio using the controllers udp sending over DS , and also recieve outputs from the rio to the DS over udp, maybe using the same thing controller rumble uses

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
R704 lays out what ports are open for team usage. It includes some UDP ports.

NB: TCP with NO_DELAY over an already-established TCP connection isn’t wildly higher-latency, especially in the context of anything that runs in a 20ms overall Rio loop. Absent packet loss, it is higher latency than UDP, but it’s also reliable (eventually) in the face of packet loss.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
Mochatitan:

but with UDP instead of TCP so that it transfers way faster

Now this is my professional gig as a manager for a team that develops some of the worlds fastest commercial messaging software.

For our purposes here in FRC , the speed difference between UDP and TCP is basically non-existent - we routinely benchmark to many millions of messages per second over TCP professionally so it’s not a protocol limitation on a network that doesn’t suffer from significant loss.

Once loss starts happening, UDP isn’t any faster than TCP (in a practical sense); it’s the guaranteed delivery of TCP that gets you.

You know good-fast-cheap; pick two?

Same thing with TCP, you trade guaranteed delivery and ordering for determinism.  You have to wait for a retransmission because you implicitly asked for guaranteed delivery and ordering. That will look like it’s slowing your perceived throughput.  With UDP, you’re just dropping packets and that isn’t helping throughput either (but you are getting what didn’t get lost pretty promptly if you do actually get it).

The difference between the two is that with UDP, your stream won’t block; you’ll just lose data.

Sounds horrible but it might not be depending on the use case.  If you can tolerate loss, UDP can keep your data timely.  Just from your high level statements, that’s probably your main concern here rather than speed of transfer because choosing between UDP and TCP won’t have an really significant impact on the speed of the transfer of the data - the handshake overhead is really pretty minimal (not getting into things like window sizing and other other stuff but even that is a really small percentage of the overall inter-process communications).

The key with UDP is that you won’t block.  If TCP message streams are being delayed, there is loss happening so your UDP communications will suffer loss as well - no free lunch.

However, if you get your UDP packet, it’s almost certainly “fresh(ish)” because it gets sent once and it either gets there or it doesn’t in a fairly short period of time (typically - but that’s not actually guaranteed either once intermediate network devices start handling things).

If you can design your packet stream so that you can tolerate loss, you’ll typically get more deterministic performance using UDP.  That means you need to be able to handle loss at your application level.  That might mean being careful about what you send and how your application uses that data; for instance, if you send packets containing a delta of some sensor value (+3, -2, etc.), you need a way to handle loss of one of those deltas otherwise you drift off (one way this gets handled is to occasionally send an “absolute” message that might be larger but more comprehensive so that folks can resync or know where to start if they join after the initial startup of the sender).  Typically if you are just sending a scalar value (like the RPM or absolute position at some point in time), you can probably handle loss at the expense of not always having the most up-to-date information.  Perfectly legit - but only if you can stand it.

In the end, TCP and UDP (just as a couple of examples) don’t generally govern the transfer speed - it’s the underlying network.  Both of them ride on IP which depends on the characteristics of the underlying network and are both subject to loss - there is no magic bit to set on a packet that says “send this super fast and don’t ever loose it” - if there was, everyone would just wire it to be on all the time.

Without more specifics on your use case, it’s hard to say go one way or the other but I suspect what you don’t want is blocking so you don’t want to go with a reliable protocol like TCP but probably want to go with an unreliable protocol like UDP but your application needs to be able to accommodate the potential for loss and still be able to move forward in a deterministic way even in the face of data loss.

There are even documented “reliable” unreliable protocols like Google’s QUIC (we’ve been doing “reliable UDP” variants in our products for decades); they basically work by being able to do what you want to handle loss in a more configurable way rather than the rigidly fixed behavior governed by the RFCs that cover TCP (you need unbending and clearly defined rules is you want widespread interoperability).

Sorry for the lengthy response - I do a lot of recruiting as part of my day job and you just touched on something that is the bulk of my initial screening interview

Just remember the most important phrase in all of engineering:

There is no such thing as a free lunch.

Sadly, many people don’t always know what “lunch” they actually ordered and then are surprised by the “bill” when it comes.

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: Wow thank you so much. Our use case we thought of was to display queues to the driver over audio, but when we did it with networktables there was a solid .3 second delay with the audio, which is bad since we are doing it as a queue for the drivers It will just be booleans, I’m not fully sure how loss works in terms of that, but if it’s a boolean that toggles between 2 states I feel like loss will not be bad on its effectiveness But it you say the speed will be similar, TCP sounds fine to not overcomplicate things.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
Mochatitan:

It will just be booleans, I’m not fully sure how loss works in terms of that, but if it’s a boolean that toggles between 2 states I feel like loss will not be bad on its effectiveness

I think you nailed that - you can consider a “boolean” to basically be an absolute state so each message is complete and doesn’t depend on any other message.

If you get it, that was the state when it was sent.

If you don’t get it, well, you wait for the next one - but you can control how frequently those get sent.

It’s all about knowing what you want to do and figuring out what the implications and requirements are.  Sounds like you did that - kudos.

Given what you described, UDP might be best.  Do you care what the state was X seconds ago or do you want the latest?  That will drive just about everything for you.

Good luck!
